entry.title: The Procurement Monthly - September 2025
entry.content:
Summary

This months report focuses on the strategic transformation of procurement and accounts payable (AP). Lots of research covering AI including deploying AI-powered orchestration, elevating procurement from tactical operations to strategic business partnership, with a focus on integrated data, governance, and human-in-the-loop decision-making. AI adoption accelerates spend analysis, supplier collaboration, automation, and compliance, but practical barriers persist—legacy systems, fragmented data, and organizational silos.

A review shows that next-generation procurement leaders prioritize resilience, sustainability, innovation, and supplier enablement, positioning modern AP and contract management as essential drivers of financial performance and business agility

Procurecon

Two procurement reports from Procurement, one sponsored by GEP about orchestration and the other by ProcureAbility about AI adoption. As they cover some of the same topics, ive combined the analysis.

GEP's report paints an expansive future where procurement evolves from functional process to strategic orchestrator. With 90% of leaders facing increasing complexity, the solution lies in comprehensive AI-powered orchestration spanning intake management, end-to-end source-to-pay, and cross-domain integration. The vision is compelling: agent-based architectures converting user intentions into automated subtasks, natural language interactions replacing complex interfaces, and procurement professionals freed from tactical work to focus on strategic value creation.

ProcureAbility's research grounds this vision in current reality. While 92% express satisfaction with AI solutions, the implementation story is more nuanced. Most organizations (59%) use AI tactically for specific initiatives rather than comprehensive integration, with 90% lacking confidence in measuring ROI. Despite strong investment intentions (88% increasing spending), challenges around proven examples and change resistance persist.

Both reports agree on fundamental shifts: procurement's democratization (40% of sourcing by non-procurement staff by 2027), the primacy of data analytics investments (70% prioritizing by 2030), and AI's role in supplier management and spend analysis. The success metrics align too – cost savings, sustainability improvements, and operational efficiency lead realized benefits.

However, the reports differ on readiness. GEP's orchestration vision assumes organizations can leap to comprehensive AI integration, while ProcureAbility's suggests most remain in moderate implementation phases. This gap between vision and reality reflects the classic technology adoption curve –success stories drive ambitious roadmaps, but broader adoption faces practical hurdles.

Beroe – AI report

According to the report, the strategic role of AI in  Procurement is now expected to deliver strategic value—cost savings, risk mitigation, supply resilience, ESG impact—not just transactional efficiency. However, legacy systems and fragmented data block progress. Success therefore depends on three pillars: Data Excellence (harmonised, contextual, trusted data), Intelligent Recommendations (contextual, prioritised insights versus static reports), and Simplicity and Relevance (role-specific, accessible information).

The report cautions that not all AI is equal. Tasks like invoice matching best suit rules-based AI, while forecasting and risk modelling need predictive or generative AI. Human judgment remains central; AI augments, not replaces, professional decision-making.

The report suggest to start with real, high-impact decision problems. Assess and close data gaps. Prioritise early wins with well-defined use cases and build from pilots to scale, always embedding AI into user workflows and maintaining human-in-the-loop governance.

Barriers and Enablers: Data readiness, explainable AI, change management, integration with existing tools, and a shift from deterministic to probabilistic thinking are all critical for success. Governance and transparency build user trust

F5 - State of AI Application Strategy Report 2025

While 96% of organizations are experimenting with AI, only 2% are “highly ready.” Most are “moderately ready,” with AI present in about one-third of applications, used in pockets not end-to-end. Readiness depends on generative/agentic AI deployment, application diversity, model diversity (mix of paid/open-source models), penetration % of apps using AI, and formal practices like data labelling. High readiness means broad, well-orchestrated integration.

Moderately Ready Organizations:

  • Generative AI and AI agents in production, but immature in governance/security and lacking orchestration.
  • Tactics: Using both paid and open-source models for flexibility; starting to deploy AI firewalls and advanced data protection; adopting AI in analytics, security, and customer experience.

Barriers to High Readiness: Siloed use cases, inconsistent policies, security concerns, especially around data use and third-party risks. Low-readiness orgs often lack skilled resources and strategy to move from pilots to scaled execution.

Comparison

As these two reports came out in the same month, there are some consistent themes:

Implications for Procurement Leaders

AI is a Strategic Partner, Not a Silver Bullet: Both reports stress that AI must be applied purposefully, integrated across processes, and always with data readiness and governance front of mind—especially given regulatory, risk, and supply chain complexity.

From Reporting to Decision Support: Move away from static dashboards to proactive, explainable recommendations and scenario simulation. AI should guide “what to do next” rather than just reporting “what happened”.

Collaborative Human-AI Models: Maintain a “human-in-the-loop” paradigm, where procurement professionals validate, explain, and direct AI recommendations. This both builds adoption and avoids “black-box” pitfalls

Comparison: Agreements and Contrasts

 

Beroe: Real Decisions

F5: AI Strategy 2025

AI’s Role

Augmenting, not replacing, human decisions; domain focus

Core infrastructure, not a feature; operational focus 

Readiness Definition

Data excellence, integrated recommendations, simplicity

Orchestrated, broad app/model integration, formal governance 

Tech Adoption Path

Real-world use cases → pilots → scale, always with HITL

Model diversity, security, broad use → mature into platform 

Key Barriers

Fragmented data, lack of explainability, trust

Siloed deployments, poor orchestration, insufficient governance 

Success Factors

Fit-for-purpose AI, role-tailored insights, continuous feedback

Hybrid AI models, formal data labelling, security/observability 

Governance Themes

Human-in-the-loop, explainability, transparency

Data governance, labelling, firewalls, compliance 

 

SSON State of Ap 2025

The report highlights AP’s shift from a cost centre to a strategic driver, underpinning cash flow, compliance, and supplier relationships.

Top Challenges: Manual data entry, invoice matching errors, compliance complexity, and increased fraud risk are leading concerns. Only 10% feel “very equipped” for e-invoicing compliance. This emphasises the complexities of e-invoicing mandates (CTC), global tax/regulation, and advanced fraud risks. The report also highlights the need for integrated, modular platforms and proactive partnership with IT and vendors.

Key metrics include touchless invoice processing rate, invoice processing time, invoices processed per FTE, cost per invoice, and late payment rate. These are strategic levers for AP excellence, focused on automation and cost control.

AP teams are adopting AI for touchless processing, fraud detection, and vendor inquiries, but most are in early phases—less than 5% have reached high (>70%) automation levels

Ardent Partners State of e-payables 2025

This report which is a staple of the research community, tracks AP’s evolution from paper-pushing to insight-driven operation over two decades. COVID-19 accelerated adoption of e-Payables but paper invoices persist (>40%) and shows that Best-in-Class AP departments achieve $2.65 per invoice cost and 2.9 days per invoice cycle (vs. $12.42 and 13.5 days “All Others”). Exception rates, touchless processing, and supplier enablement are critical differentiators.

The report states that the key priorities are the need to deploy comprehensive e-Payables solutions, improving analytics/reporting, and supplier enablement are top priorities. Supplier participation is identified as the “Achilles heel” for digital transformation. Best-in-Class AP teams have much higher adoption rates of automated routing/workflow (80%), e-Invoicing (79%), e-Payments (77%), and tend to use integrated payment networks.

AP’s strategic involvement in cash management, supplier management, and business intelligence is growing but uneven. Collaboration with procurement and treasury is essential for resilience (e.g., managing tariffs, payment timing, supply risk).

44% use AI today; 75% expected to within 12 months. Main objective is increased automation, but secondary priorities include forecasting, cost reduction, and stakeholder satisfaction.

Both the SSON and Ardent Partners 2025 reports position accounts payable (AP) as a critical, evolving function—moving from manual, transactional activity to an intelligent, value-generating hub within enterprises.

Comparison & Contrast.

Both reports stress the importance of tight alignment between procurement and AP for supplier enablement, payment optimization, and strategic sourcing. Procurement must partner with AP to drive spend visibility, compliance, and process innovation

Both agree that AP must transform into a strategic partner for procurement, finance, and the broader enterprise, and that success hinges on automation, intelligent analytics, supplier enablement, and compliance.

Both stress that AI adoption and modern e-Payables technologies will accelerate AP’s strategic contribution in the next 2–3 years, but acknowledge both barriers and opportunities remain

Area

SSON: State of Accounts Payable 2025

Ardent Partners: State of e-Payables 2025

Commonality

Difference

Strategic AP Role

Value centre, unified payment, embedded AI, continuous improvement

Insight hub, process control, spend/cash management, AI as enabler

Elevating AP to strategic, proactive function

SSON stresses compliance/fraud/data quality; Ardent focuses on benchmarks and transformation maturity

Technology Adoption

Unified payments, touchless automation, modular platforms, phased approach

Comprehensive e-Payables, straight-through processing, payment networks, supplier enablement

Automation and integration drive efficiency and quality

SSON highlights touchless invoice challenges with non-PO invoices; Ardent quantifies automation maturity

AI & Analytics

Machine learning and AI for fraud, query handling, translation

AI for automation, forecasting, cost reduction; new metrics CAIT/SPOR

AI as future driver, but adoption is early

Ardent provides deeper metrics and analytics frameworks

Supplier Enablement

Centralized data, portals, feedback loops, high e-invoice adoption

Identifies supplier enablement as Achilles heel, calls for greater digital onboarding

Supplier participation key to transformation

SSON offers best practices; Ardent quantifies enablement gaps and solutions

Compliance & Risk

Proactive, embedded compliance for global mandates; layered fraud strategy

Compliance aligns with e-Invoicing, spend analytics; fraud prevention partnered with audit/IT

Compliance is central, fraud risk is rising

SSON more granular on regulation frameworks, e-invoicing challenges

 

North Carolina procurement and supply chain study

The latest NCSU study finds procurement and supply chain leaders are finally converging on shared strategic goals, but old operational silos haven’t vanished yet. Resilience, quality compliance, and sustainability now overshadow traditional cost and delivery metrics, reflecting the need to thrive amid ongoing disruption. Despite strategic alignment, execution gaps persist and can cost businesses dearly through slow decisions, increased risks, and missed opportunities for supply chain performance.

The report states that orchestration—coordinating people, processes, and tech has emerged as the practical fix for these gaps. The study shows workflow efficiency and cost savings are the top metrics organizations use to measure orchestration’s ROI. However adoption faces challenges: data quality, security concerns, and skills gaps stand out as the biggest of them.

The report states that leaders should prioritize cross-functional collaboration on risk and financial outcomes, invest in orchestration technology, pilot AI in key areas, and balance technical solutions with human readiness.

World Commerce and Contracting  - Contract Management

This report “Contract Management: An Overlooked Driver of Business Agility and Financial Performance” spotlights a hidden source of value erosion for organizations: dysfunctional contract management practices. The research reveals that businesses lose an average of 9% annual value due to poor contracting, with top-performing organizations limiting losses to 3%, while the worst experience up to 15% erosion. Procurement leaders are urged to examine how fragmented, slow, and rigid contracts undermine agility and financial outcomes.

The report points out recurring structural issues: siloed processes across Legal, Procurement, Finance, inconsistent skills among contract practitioners, and severe data fragmentation—contract data is scattered over an average of 24 separate systems. 83% of executives state contracts are too rigid to adapt during market shifts, directly impacting resilience and speed.

Effective contract management enables faster responses to disruption, operational alignment, and better exploitation of technologies like AI. The report’s roadmap to maturity encourages organizations to unlock competitive advantage and financial performance by treating contracting as a strategic enabler rather than a bureaucratic hurdle

Insights from CPO’s

Ahead of DPW in October this year, DPW released an e-book from DPW Amsterdam 2024 which has five leading Chief Procurement Officers to share actionable strategies shaping the next era of procurement.

Iris van den Harst (Equans Netherlands) urged starting small—focusing sustainability efforts with top-impact suppliers and industry alignment to standardize requests, which builds rapid credibility and measurable change. Shashi Mandapaty (Johnson & Johnson) frames procurement’s evolution as indispensable to corporate growth, advocating for supplier innovation, data stewardship, and an unyielding “no trade-off” mindset to create universal value across customers, employees, suppliers, and communities.

Modernizing procurement’s operation is another recurring theme. Sopan Shah (IHG Hotels & Resorts) recommends aligning tech with business strategy, leveraging new digital tools, and fostering cultures that allow experimentation and intelligent risk-taking. Klaus Staubitzer (Siemens) shows how embedding resilience across multi-tier supply chains and scaling pilots with clear KPIs turns procurement into a value-driving partner, while ensuring that AI initiatives genuinely support human expertise.

Fannie Boulanger (Airbnb) flips compliance-led procurement on its head, showing how culture-first leadership, speedy category strategy, and branding of procurement as a service transform stakeholder buy-in, especially during hypergrowth.

For procurement leaders, these lessons mean building innovation-centric teams, investing strategically in data and tech that empower—not replace—human judgment, and making procurement a central force for sustainable business impact

As always reach out to discuss more, and always happy to hear your thoughts!

entry.title: Re: Keine Berechtigung in Finanzen und Recht - Lizenznutzung
entry.content:
Hi Markus,

To access the Private Cloud Consumption card within the Finance & Legal - SAP for Me, it is necessary for an S-user to have the specific authorization called 'Access License Utilization for Private Cloud'. Upon reviewing your S-user ID, I noticed that your current permissions do not include this required authorization. Typically, when an S-user lacks this authorization, they need to reach out to their Super Administrator to have it granted. 

In order to resolve this problem, I have manually adjusted the permissions for your S-user ID as you are the Super Administrator but do not have the necessary authorization. You should now be able to access the Private Cloud Consumption card without any difficulties.

For additional details, please refer to the following KBAs:

3440820 - Data not loading in Consumption application - SAP for Me

2981882 - S-user ID authorization requirements - SAP for Me

If you encounter any further challenges or have additional questions, please don’t hesitate to let me know. 

Best regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Automatic Sales order exctraction
entry.content:
Dear SKAE,

I see that we are implementing 4X9. As per below please see if the steps as per set up guide.

https://me.sap.com/processnavigator/SolS/EARL_SolS-013/2508/SolP/4X9?region=DE

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a376cd9ea00d476b96f18dea1247e6a5/2dcf49a616b842b096e0a3cad4dac458.html 

This app calls the Document Information Extraction service to extract data from purchase order files. Currently, the app supports purchase orders in English or German (see Supported Languages (Base Edition)). You do not need to have an enterprise account on SAP Business Technology Platform (which requires a separate license) to use the service.

1. Open the Intelligent Scenario Management app (business role SAP_BR_ANALYTICS_SPECIALIST), and search
for intelligent scenario SO_AUTO_EXTRACTION.
2. Within the intelligent scenario, choose the default version.
3. On the Deployments tab, activate the default deployment for all.
 Note
If you cannot find the intelligent scenario, the setup for 4X9 has failed. Raise a BCP ticket on component
SD-SLS-IMP-DOX.

Regards

Sahil Grover

__PRESENT

entry.title: Re: Table TOBJ list of authorization EHP8
entry.content: Hello @manthana99c17, SU25 is the way how to apply changes done by patch, SAP Note, upgrade, into your roles. In case of too much changes I guess it could be splitted directly using Step 2a - at first only for standard SAP space, including all steps as usually. Then it could be runned again, only for customer applications in customer space, all steps as above. Sometimes upgrade, SAP Note, patching brings no changes in authorization, sometimes yes. You can run SU25 every day but it will display only changes in authorizations in impact of installations on application level. No installation, no change 😁 Regarding auto update from SAP system, you mean regular maintenance proceeded on SAP system in SAP Cloud? As we are currently running S/4 conversion and moving our SAPs into SAP RISE Cloud, a final procedure how to deal with is not established yet. But thanks to your question, the first check using table/s USOBX* to see if anything has changed sounds like a good idea. If you will not run SU25, no changes would be applied into roles. It means if EHP8 would bring new auth object/s, new default values, or removal of any auth object/s, etc., for your roles this change will exist only after SU25. Of course, you can check if is needed, if any change has been caused, it's on you. But if changes with an impact to authorization happen, until SU25 finished, they can cause strange auth error/s. BR, Olga

entry.title: Re: set the condition rate using the attributes sent from...
entry.content: When using the CRM_COND_COM BADI to modify condition values in CRMD_ORDER, the BADI is designed to execute on save, not on a simple 'Enter' key press. The IPC (Internet Pricing and Configurator) executes more frequently, including on 'Enter.' The issue you're facing is a timing and data synchronization problem. Your BADI logic runs on save, updating a value, but the IPC re-calculates before this change is fully processed and communicated back to it. Consequently, the IPC's pricingCondition object doesn't have the updated value from your BADI when it performs its calculation, leading to the condition rate not changing. To correctly change the condition rate, the modification must be handled within the IPC userexit itself, using the data passed to it, or by ensuring the data is available to the IPC before its calculation step. The pricingCondition.setConditionRate() method is the correct way to change the value within the IPC, but it must be provided with the correct, updated data at the time of execution.

entry.title: Re: e-Doc Submission Error from SD Module Due to Missing...
entry.content: Check the Configuration in Table EDOCOMPANYACTIV Go to transaction SE16N or SM30 and open the table EDOCOMPANYACTIV. Verify the document types configured for your company code and country (Turkey). Ensure that SD_INVOICE is listed and active for Turkey. Update the Source Document Type In your SD billing process or e-Document configuration, replace SD_INVNOAC with SD_INVOICE. This change ensures compatibility with the Turkish Revenue Administration (GIB) integration. Adjust the e-Document Cockpit Settings Go to EDOC_COCKPIT and check the document type mappings. Make sure that the correct document type (SD_INVOICE) is used for Turkey. Test the Flow Again After updating the document type, reprocess the export document. Ensure the discharge date and other mandatory fields are populated before sending.

entry.title: SAP清洁核心白皮书 - 引言和价值总结(1)
entry.content:
本文内容主要来自Clean core extensibility白皮书

SAP发现企业在实施定制化拓展时往往遇到很多问题，包括但不限于：标准功能是否满足需求，有哪些拓展方式是可选的，不同方式可以达成什么样的效果，未来该如何维护这些拓展才能保证持续的创新能力等等。

所以SAP推出了Clean Core方法论，为组织在拓展核心IT系统时提供指导意见，帮助组织打造一个清洁的核心。

清洁核心方法论下又包含了五个维度的清洁，分别是业务流程/拓展/数据/集成/运营 维度的清洁性，本白皮书主要关注拓展层面的清洁核心原则

 

如果您对BTP感兴趣，BTP个人精选内容目录 | SAP Blogs 可能有更多你需要的内容

 

白皮书内容较多，本文包含了章节1和2的内容，以下是全部内容总览

  • 摘要
  • 第1章.引言
  • 第2章.为什么Clean Core很重要
    • 探讨Clean Core背后的业务驱动因素、遗留系统的局限性，以及Clean Core如何启用创新、敏捷性和更容易的升级。
  • 第3章.Clean Core对扩展性的意义
    • 介绍Clean Core原则，重点关注扩展性选项，包括”体内On Stack”和”体外Side by Side”模型、Clean Core等级概念以及合作伙伴解决方案的一致性。
  • 第4章.如何实现扩展性的Clean Core
    • 提供实用的、分步的治理、测量和实施清洁扩展的框架。涵盖工具、方法论（如SAP应用扩展方法论）和监控和执行Clean Core遵循的KPI。
  • 第5章.常见问题
    • 解决关于Clean Core扩展性战略、技术和实施的常见问题和关注。
  • 第6章.附录
    • 提供支持材料、链接和模板，帮助有效实施Clean Core战略。

 

摘要

为什么Clean Core很重要

随着时间的推移，许多ERP环境会因自定义代码、未记录的变更和难以维护的集成而变得臃肿。这限制了灵活性，减缓了升级速度，并增加了总拥有成本。

Clean Core方法通过促进标准流程的使用和启用战略性差异化扩展来解决这些挑战。它专注于构建由无缝集成、高效运营和强大数据质量支持的韧性业务流程。

通过采用Clean Core方法，客户可以：

  • 加速创新周期
  • 最小化技术债务
  • 简化系统维护和升级

Clean Core并非限制开发灵活性，而是确保扩展以正确的方式完成——在满足业务需求的同时提供长期稳定性、可扩展性和创新就绪等价值。

 

新内容：3层模型的演进——引入Clean Core等级概念

SAP正在通过Clean Core等级概念发展其ERP扩展指导原则，这是一个新模型，旨在简化标准，为管理SAP S/4HANA Cloud中的自定义代码提供更实用的方法，这个模型也包括了Classic ABAP开发方式的分类。

基于之前的3层模型，这个新的成熟度模型基于其架构完整性、升级安全性和与Clean Core原则的一致性，将扩展分为四个不同等级（A、B、C和D）

这种方法允许对扩展的质量和升级稳定性进行更细粒度的评估，不再只是简单的"清洁"与"不清洁"的二元分类。核心建议仍然是"SAP BTP优先"策略，目标是将全部拓展维持在最高等级A级，

但新模型也承认复杂系统环境的现实，支持客户自由选择其Clean Core之旅。基本原则保持不变：将扩展与标准SAP代码解耦以确保升级稳定性。

 

工作原理：四个Clean Core等级的解释

核心的每个扩展都应该使用标准化方法进行评估，基于其开发方式/与核心的解耦程度/升级或维护的难易程度评估其Clean Core等级：

等级A：使用SAP Build扩展——使用仅公开发布且稳定的接口的完全合规扩展，由正式稳定性合同支持。

  • “体外Side by Side”扩展：基于SAP BTP构建，使用专业代码和低代码工具进行应用开发和流程自动化。
  • “体内On Stack”扩展：在SAP S/4HANA Cloud内构建，使用ABAP Cloud开发模型和公开发布的API。

等级B：利用经典API：使用SAP的经典API和技术——定义良好、有文档记录且通常升级稳定的接口。

等级C：访问内部对象：依赖SAP内部对象的部分合规扩展，为遗留场景提供灵活性。为降低升级风险，SAP提供SAP对象变更日志，帮助及早识别不兼容变更并主动规划升级。

等级D：不推荐的扩展：不被视为"清洁"的扩展，使用明确不推荐的对象或技术（例如，在云化存储库中标记为"noAPI"的对象/对SAP对象的修改/对SAP表的直接Write访问/或隐式增强implicit enhancements），这类拓展代表了最高等级的风险，并很容易创造重大技术债务。

 

结论：赋能战略现代化之旅

Clean Core等级概念通过以下方式提供切实的好处：

提供差异化评估：为经典ABAP代码提供更细致、基于风险的评估。

增加透明度：清楚地定义低风险的"经典API"，与高风险的"不推荐使用"对象。

提供实用的前进路径：帮助客户更有效地管理现有代码库并优先修复最高风险扩展（等级D）。

 

Clean Core等级概念并未改变最终目标：构建解耦的、升级稳定的扩展，以等级A为理想状态。它提供了一个更实用和透明的框架来实现这一目标。

它赋能组织做出明智决策，理解与其自定义代码相关的具体风险，并战略性地规划其IT现代化的努力。通过优先消除等级D扩展，并利用等级B和C的更大透明度，客户可以减少技术债务，简化未来升级，并保持SAP S/4HANA核心系统的长期完整性和敏捷性。

Clean Core等级概念和实现扩展性Clean Core指导的更多详细信息在以下章节中提供。

 

1.引言

SAP软件旨在跨业务线和行业提供广泛而深入的功能。然而，没有哪两个企业是完全相同的，企业需要的不仅仅是标准流程。SAP认识到了这一点，并赋能客户能够在满足定制化需求的同时，保持创新，和核心系统稳定性。

SAP Clean Core鼓励组织对非差异化流程采用标准化、升级稳定的功能；同时为标准功能不满足的需求提供灵活的扩展性选项。一个清洁的核心代表了一个稳定可靠的数字基础——减少复杂性、技术债务和升级工作，使创新能够在最有价值的地方发生。

为支持不同的转型需求，SAP S/4HANA Cloud提供两个版本：

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud公有版提供即用型SaaS ERP解决方案，具有无缝的SAP管理更新和严格治理的扩展性模型，通过设计保持核心清洁。
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud私有版将更大的责任放在客户身上，要求客户深思熟虑地管理升级和扩展——同时牢记相同的Clean Core目标。

本白皮书专门关注SAP Clean Core战略的扩展性原则。它提供了两个SAP S/4HANA Cloud版本扩展性模型的详细视图，包括扩展选项、架构考虑、治理建议和实施指导，帮助组织构建业务差异化创新而不损害核心完整性。通过遵循这些指导原则，客户可以开发升级稳定、可维护的扩展，这些扩展符合Clean Core标准并支持云上的持续创新。

 

2.为什么Clean Core很重要

克服障碍并释放创新 

技术创新的加速步伐带来了巨大的机遇——但只对那些准备好的组织。许多企业被其旧的Legacy本地系统所拖累，无法快速响应变化。常见挑战包括：

  • 缺乏标准化
  • 过度定制
  • 数据质量差

这些障碍增加了复杂性，降低了敏捷性，使得企业难以利用新兴技术和趋势，如AI。为了克服这些限制，组织需要通过Clean Core方法转型和现代化其系统。这意味着用标准化，模块化和灵活的系统替代本地系统日渐增长的复杂性，符合Clean Core标准的系统更易于维护和发展。

Clean Core帮助组织实现：

  • 更快的创新周期
  • 加速价值实现
  • 改善整个业务的敏捷性
  • 增强数据质量，驱动AI驱动创新

通过采用Clean Core原则，企业可以释放持续的、增量的创新，并随着时间的推移提供更大的业务价值——将其ERP系统从瓶颈转变为增长的催化剂。

 

 

关于本文内容有任何问题或见解，欢迎在评论区留下你的想法，如果时间紧迫，也可以直接联系到我 arthuryang1996@foxmail.com，感谢你的时间

entry.title: Re: Data Extraction from S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hello @Germaine 

Thank you for your question. Below are possible ways to achieve your Data extraction

You can consider the following options:

  1. You can build custom CDS Views in S/4HANA Cloud to expose the fields you need for export. See  Data Extraction options. The options cover master data and transactional data EXTRACTING DATA FROM SAP S/4HANA CLOUD USING THE CUSTOMER DATA RETURN APP
  2. SAP provides an Attachment API in Public Cloud to retrieve files  Manage attachments using this synchronous inbound service. You can also consult the Fiori App Library.
  3. You also have the option to extract data using tools like SAP Data Intelligence, ETL tools, middleware platforms and cloud data platforms. These can be combined with the custom CDS/OData endpoints. Also you can use the Customer Data Return App. EXTRACTING DATA FROM SAP S/4HANA CLOUD USING THE CUSTOMER DATA RETURN APP AND TRANSFERRING IT

There are some limitations you should be aware of. To achieve what is described in those steps, you have to ensure the right communications arrangement / API authorisations are in place. Attachments API may also be a limitation due to size. Also considering you want to export large data, this can lead to performance issues.

Here is my recommendation summarised

To ensure smooth extraction, ensure you define scope, use the CDS views to expose all needed master data, used attachment API or script to download them in batches, set up scripts or use ETL tools (e.g., SAP Data Intelligence), ensure your data is complete so you don’t miss anything and finally organise your data or files in a repository with metadata.

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: CDS Table Entity
entry.content:
What is CDS Table Entity? 

A CDS Table entity defines a database table in ABAP CDS as an ABAP-managed database object. 

Table entities are like a special container that provide a persistence layer for ABAP applications. 

 It supports CDS associations, semantic meta data with CDS annotations and typing with both CDS simple types and CDS enumerated types. 

Advantages  

> By using CDS table entity we can perform the CRUD (Select, update, modify, delete) operations and also it can be used as a data type in ABAP. 

>CDS entities as the active persistence layer in scenarios with or without draft capabilities. 

>When you're building a business object (like something that handles customer orders or travel bookings), you need a place to store its data permanently. You can do this by using table entities, which act like real database tables. This setup makes sure your business object's data is saved and managed, so it’s always available when needed. 

>We can also control who can read the data in these tables by setting access rules, so only the right people can see sensitive information. 

>It helps you organize data by showing how different parts are connected—like building a tree structure where one item is the parent and others are children. This is called a composition tree, and it helps model complex relationships in your data. 

 >Annotations at the element level can be used to add semantic information, such as text labels.  

Disadvantages  

>Table entities are not supported for draft persistence as of now. The reason is that currently include structures are not supported for table entities, which prevents including a draft admin include required for RAP draft tables. 

>Extending table entities is currently not supported. 

>Currently, CDS table entities cannot be used in ABAP analytics for building analytical data models, such as cubes and dimensions. They can't be enabled for data-extraction. 

 Defining table Entities 

Let’s take a look at the delightful syntax that brings a table entity to life!" 

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED 

@EndUserText.label: 'Table Entity' 

@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass: #APPLICATION_DATA 

@ClientHandling.type: #CLIENT_INDEPENDENT 

define table entity Entity_Name 

{ 

    [field] 
    [association] 

} 

🌟Let’s light up the concept with a hands-on example! 

We can create a Table Entity with key or without key field as well. 

Without Key field  

  

🌟In this example, we’ll be creating a table entity featuring a key field to uniquely identify each record.             

                                           

💡Before we dive into performing CRUD operations in this class, there's an important note to highlight: we’ll be using a specific interface IF_OO_ADT_CLASSRUN that contains a dedicated method main for executing these operations. While it's technically possible to perform the actions without it, using this interface ensures that the output is properly displayed in the console.

⚠️To ensure smooth execution of the class, it's essential to implement the IF_OO_ADT_CLASSRUN interface. Without it, the system will display the message below.                                                   

✨Now, let’s build a class that handles CRUD operations seamlessly using our CDS table entity.                 

   

🚀Next, we’ll proceed with inserting records into the CDS table entity to demonstrate its functionality in action. 

                                              

Output: 

We can see the output in console

🔍Let’s now perform the read operation and retrieve the records we just inserted into the CDS table entity. 

Output:

🌟"Let's proceed with the update operation and retrieve the records to review the changes. Similarly, we can perform modifications as needed!"

Output:

🌟"Let's move on to the final step—performing the delete operation and retrieving the records to confirm the changes!" 

Output:

Quick Recap 🧠

CDS Table Entities offer a powerful way to define and manage persistent data in ABAP applications. They support CRUD operations, semantic annotations, and complex data modeling through composition trees. While they’re not yet compatible with draft persistence or analytics, they remain a key building block for structuring business objects in ABAP.

💬If you’ve got thoughts, questions, or experiences with CDS Table Entities, feel free to drop them in the comments—I’d love to hear how you're using them in your ABAP projects.

entry.title: Safe quantities in orders from being rescheduled?
entry.content:
Hello,

I am new to this community, so apologies already if my questionning is kinda vague, since I am also not very much into the technical things either 🙂

However, since I am stuck within all the ressources that I have to find a solution, I am now reaching out to you.

Every night we have a job running called "rescheduler" which assigns quantities of products anew, according to priorities, but also to delivery date. So, for example it takes the product quantities from one order that has the delivery date set for 30.11. and adds them to an order with a delivery date 22.11. (even though this order was received already wayyy earlier). While this is quite nice for products that come regularly on stock, this is not so nice for products that are presold, where we rather require a first come, first serve setting (or even exit products).

So, I am wondering if there is any setting in SAP (maybe directly in the orders or with the article) that protects them from being touched by the "rescheduling"?

Any idea on this would be highly appreciated.

Thank you and best regards

Dietmar

entry.title: Re: Formula Calculation of 'Best Possible' DSO
entry.content:
Hi @12345678901 

Thank you for your question to the community. Let me walk you through the points you raised.

On your first point, you do not need to add another app to display Best possible DSO. It is already available in the average DSO app. However, this only appears when the underlying calculation can be derived. So, if you only see actual DSO, then it means the filters or data conditions for the best possible DSO are not met.

On your second point, sample filter setup to replicate Best possible DSO calculation. Open Manage Customer Line Items app, apply the filter Your Cocd to your company code àfor the status choose Open Items àOpen Key date to last day of reporting period à Item type: normal items + special G/L transactions àadapt filters: journal entry à journal entry category à normal document.

Finally, make sure to export or aggregate your total open receivables.

Please reference Days Sales Outstanding  link for more details.

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: A better way to create the Root-Child-Grandchild hierachy in RAP
entry.content:
The RAP Framework supports Parent - Child - Grandchild - Great Grandchild - and so forth.

There are beautiful blog posts on how to do this:

  • How to design managed RAP business objects with 3 or more levels of nodes : Shows the basic idea.
  • Create Root-Child-Grandchild-Great Grandchild relationship using RAP : Shows the actual implementation.

Both of them relies on storing a reference to the root in each and every descendant. As in: a child has a reference to the parent, and a grandchild (or great grandchild) has a reference to the root parent as well.

This is required so that in the Behavior Definition of each descendant, the association to the root can be used for `lock` and `authorization`.

But this has got me thinking: Why do we have to store the reference to the root in each descendant like this? Couldn't we do something like:

Grandchild._Child._Parent
"or even
GreatGrandchild._Grandchild._Child._Parent

 If this worked, we would need to store the reference to the parent only in the child, therefore saving space on Grandchild and Great Grandchild.

With that said, let's dive in and test this. Here I only build Parent, Child, and Grandchild.

Database tables

Parent:

@EndUserText.label : 'parent'
@AbapCatalog.enhancement.category : #NOT_EXTENSIBLE
@AbapCatalog.tableCategory : #TRANSPARENT
@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #A
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #RESTRICTED
define table z_parenttest {

  key client            : abap.clnt not null;
  key uuid              : sysuuid_x16 not null;
  local_created_by      : abp_creation_user;
  local_created_at      : abp_creation_tstmpl;
  local_last_changed_by : abp_locinst_lastchange_user;
  local_last_changed_at : abp_locinst_lastchange_tstmpl;
  last_changed_at       : abp_lastchange_tstmpl;

}

 Child:

@EndUserText.label : 'CHILD'
@AbapCatalog.enhancement.category : #NOT_EXTENSIBLE
@AbapCatalog.tableCategory : #TRANSPARENT
@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #A
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #RESTRICTED
define table z_childtest {

  key client  : abap.clnt not null;
  key uuid    : sysuuid_x16 not null;
  parent_uuid : sysuuid_x16;

}

 Grandchild:

@EndUserText.label : 'Grandchild'
@AbapCatalog.enhancement.category : #NOT_EXTENSIBLE
@AbapCatalog.tableCategory : #TRANSPARENT
@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #A
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #RESTRICTED
define table z_gchildtest {

  key client : abap.clnt not null;
  key uuid   : sysuuid_x16 not null;
  child_uuid : sysuuid_x16;

}

As you can see, the grandchild doesn't have a field for the parent's UUID.

Interface View

Parent

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'PARENT'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
define root view entity ZI_PARENT
  as select from z_parenttest
  composition [0..*] of zi_child as _Child
{
  key uuid                  as Uuid,
      @Semantics.user.createdBy: true
      local_created_by      as CreatedBy,
      @Semantics.systemDateTime.createdAt: true
      local_created_at      as CreatedAt,
      @Semantics.user.lastChangedBy: true
      local_last_changed_by as LastChangedBy,
      @Semantics.systemDateTime.lastChangedAt: true
      last_changed_at       as LastChangedAt,
      @Semantics.systemDateTime.localInstanceLastChangedAt: true
      local_last_changed_at as LocalLastChangedAt,
      _Child
}

 Child

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'child'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
define view entity zi_child
  as select from z_childtest
  association to parent ZI_PARENT    as _Parent on $projection.ParentUuid = _Parent.Uuid
  composition [0..*] of ZI_GRANDCHILD as _GrandChild
{
  key uuid        as Uuid,
      parent_uuid as ParentUuid,
      _Parent,
      _GrandChild
}

Everything looks normal so far. Now for what we came here for: The Grandchild!

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'GRANDE'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
define view entity ZI_GRANDCHILD
  as select from z_gchildtest
  association to parent zi_child as _Child on $projection.ChildUuid = _Child.Uuid
{
  key uuid       as Uuid,
      child_uuid as ChildUuid,
      _Child,
      //You will get an error saying you have to include this
      //If you want to use _Child._Parent
      _Child.ParentUuid as ParentUUID,
      _Child._Parent as _Parent,
      
}

 And just like that, the association to parent is made, without having to store a reference.

From this point onward: Projection View, MDE, Behavior... Everything should be the same as in the mentioned blogs.

Thanks for reading my blog and I wish you a pleasant day.

entry.title: Re: ME21N copy qty from contract to PO
entry.content:
Yes in standard SAP, when you create a PO with reference to a contract, the default quantity in the PO item is normally taken from the target quantity in the contract item only if the contract is quantity‑based (target quantity maintained in the contract item), not purely value‑based, the adoption rules in customizing allow the quantity to be copied and you haven’t already got a default quantity logic in place like info record, material master, service master that overrides it.

If your contract is a service contract with UoM = KM, and you’re always getting “1” in the PO, it usually means the contract is value‑based (target value maintained, no target quantity), so SAP can’t copy a quantity. Or, the adoption of quantity from the reference document is switched off in your copy control settings for purchasing. Or, for service POs, the system is defaulting to 1 because the service line in the service master or outline agreement has no quantity, only a limit.

entry.title: Re: Safe quantities in orders from being rescheduled?
entry.content:
Yes SAP does give you ways to “protect” certain sales order items from being touched by the nightly rescheduling run (SDV03V02 / V_V2), so that they keep their original confirmed quantities and dates.

Go to your sales order → Item → Shipping tab → field Fix qty/date. If this flag is set, the rescheduling program will not change the confirmed quantity or date for that schedule line. Perfect for presold or “exit” products where you want to honour the original confirmation (first‑come, first‑served).

entry.title: Re: Custom Action on SAP BTP Build Process Automation
entry.content:
Hello @Rawel 

Thank you for your question. 

Base on your screenshots i can see you are trying to post attachments using the API_CV_ATTACHMENT_SRV service. The error you are experiencing is expected because the attachment content set itself is only meant to read available content and does not expose a POST method.

To post attachments you must use the attachment set entity, the payload must include metada containing binary content.

The following references provide more details

Technical name: API_CV_ATTACHMENT_SRV

Access Fiori apps via SAP Build Work Zone Site with Federated SAP S/4HANA Content

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: SAP BDC Trial System takes long time for setup
entry.content: I too faced same issue for almost a week. Then I realized my browser my S user account logged in. I would request you to please log off from your S user account and relogin with your trial account login. This works.

entry.title: How to use MessageManager in SAPUI5 - Step-by-Step Guide
entry.content:
What is MessageManager?

The MessageManager in SAPUI5 helps us to manage and display messages like errors, warnings, or informational notes in our application. These messages often appear in a MessagePopover or directly next to form fields, giving users real-time feedback.

Let’s go through step by step to understand how we can use MessageManager effectively in our SAPUI5 app.

 

Step 1: Register the View with MessageManager

Before displaying any messages, we need to register our view with the MessageManager. This tells SAPUI5 to monitor form fields and automatically bind any messages to the right controls.

Add this line in the init function of our Component.js (or) Main.view.xml:

sap.ui.getCore().getMessageManager().registerObject(this.getView(), true);

Screenshot 1.1

Please Note: If  we're using manifest.json, there's also a declarative way to register it, but for simplicity, we’re going with manual registration here.

 

Step 2: Add a MessagePopover Control

To show the messages visually, add a MessagePopover in our view. We can do this in XML or JavaScript.

XML Example:

<Button text="Show Messages" press="onOpenMessagePopover" />

Screenshot 1.2.1

Please Note: Just for your understanding, as per the screenshot, I have used Main.view.xml for button which could trigger the validation based on the user input on this form fields.

<MessagePopover id="messagePopover" items="{ path: '/messages' }">
    <items>
        <MessageItem type="{type}" title="{message}" 
            description="{description}" />
    </items>
</MessagePopover>

Screenshot 1.2.2

Please Note: Just for your understanding, as per the screenshot, I have used separate fragment for for MessagePopover which could pop up when while validation has been called off.

 

Step 3: Add Messages to the MessageManager

Whenever we want to show a message (e.g., an error if a form field is empty), use the addMessages() method:

sap.ui.getCore().getMessageManager().addMessages(
    new sap.ui.core.message.Message({
        message: "Please fill all required fields.",
        type: sap.ui.core.MessageType.Error,
        target: "/field", // Optional: bind to a specific field
        processor: this.getView().getModel()
    })
);

Screenshot 1.3

Please Note: Just for your understanding, as per the screenshot, I have used separate method as addErrorMessage to add dynamic error messages for multiple forms.

Available Message Types:

  • Error
  • Warning
  • Success
  • Information

 

Step 4: Open the MessagePopover

When the user clicks the button (or at the right moment in our flow), open the MessagePopover:

onOpenMessagePopover: function (oEvent) {
    if (!this._oMessagePopover) {
        this._oMessagePopover = this.byId("messagePopover");
    }
    this._oMessagePopover.openBy(oEvent.getSource());
}

Screenshot 1.4

Please Note: Just for your understanding, as per the screenshot, I have used separate fragment for for MessagePopover which could pop up when Button has been triggered. (ex. while user clicks the submit button without filling the mandatory fields)

 

Step 5: Clear Messages

If needed (e.g., after a successful save), we can clear all messages like this:

sap.ui.getCore().getMessageManager().removeAllMessages();

Screenshot 1.5

Please Note: Just for your understanding, as per the screenshot, I have used separate method as removeErrorMessage to remove dynamic error messages.

 

Complete Flow - Here’s the full flow in a nutshell:

  1. Register our view with the MessageManager
  2. Add a MessagePopover control
  3. Insert messages into the MessageManager
  4. Trigger the MessagePopover on user interaction
  5. Clear messages when appropriate

 

Complete Code: (For Reference)

MessageManager.controller.js

sap.ui.define([
  "./BaseController",
  "sap/ui/core/message/Message",
  "sap/ui/core/Fragment"
],

  function (BaseController, Message, Fragment) {
    "use strict";

    return BaseController.extend("testapp.controller.MessageManager", {
      onInit: function () {
        var oMessageManager, oView;
        oView = this.getView();

        oMessageManager = sap.ui.getCore().getMessageManager();
        oView.setModel(oMessageManager.getMessageModel(), "message");

        oMessageManager.registerObject(oView, true);
      },

      onOpenMessagePopover: function (oEvent) {
        var oSource = oEvent.getSource();

        this._createMessagePopover().then(function (oMessagePopover) {
          oMessagePopover.openBy(oSource);
        });
      },

      _createMessagePopover: function (oEvent) {

        var oView = this.getView();

        if (!this._pMessagePopover) {
          this._pMessagePopover = Fragment.load({
            id: oView.getId(),
            name: "testapp.fragment.MessagePopover"
          }).then(function (oMessagePopover) {
            oView.addDependent(oMessagePopover);
            return oMessagePopover;
          });
        }
        return this._pMessagePopover;
      },

      addErrorMessage: function (sMessage, sTarget) {
        var oMessage = new Message({
          message: sMessage,
          type: MessageType.Error,
          target: sTarget,
          processor: this.oModel,
          activeTitle: true
        });
        sap.ui.getCore().getMessageManager().addMessages(oMessage);
      },

      removeErrorMessages: function () {
        sap.ui.getCore().getMessageManager().removeAllMessages(
          new Message({
            target: "/uiDataInput",
            processor: this.oModel
          })
        );
      },

      onContinue: function (oEvent) {
        const oSource = oEvent.getSource();
        if (!this.uiOrderFieldValidation()) {
          oSource.setBusy(true);
          Promise.resolve().finally(() => {
            oSource.setBusy(false);
          });
        }
      },

      uiOrderFieldValidation: function () {
        let bOrderHasErrors = false;
        this.removeErrorMessages();
        const oResourceBundle = this.getOwnerComponent().getModel("i18n").getResourceBundle();

        var sErrorMessage = oResourceBundle.getText("ORDER_FORM_ERROR_MESSAGE_GENERAL");
        const sFirstName = this.oModel.getProperty("/uiDataInput/firstname");
        if (!sFirstName || sFirstName.trim().length === 0) {
          const sNameErrorMessage = oResourceBundle.getText("ORDER_FORM_ERROR_MESSAGE_USER_FIRSTNAME");
          this.addErrorMessage(sNameErrorMessage, "/uiDataInput/firstName");
          sErrorMessage = sNameErrorMessage;
          bOrderHasErrors = true;
        }

        const sLastName = this.oModel.getProperty("/uiDataInput/lastName");
        if (!sLastName || sLastName.trim().length === 0) {
          const sLastNameErrorMessage = oResourceBundle.getText("ORDER_FORM_ERROR_MESSAGE_USER_LASTNAME");
          this.addErrorMessage(sLastNameErrorMessage, "/uiDataInput/lastName");
          sErrorMessage = sLastNameErrorMessage;
          bOrderHasErrors = true;
        }

        //Similarly you can check for all the remaining fields

        return bOrderHasErrors;
      }

    });
  });

 

MessageManager.view.xml

<mvc:View controllerName="testapp.controller.MessageManager"
    xmlns:mvc="sap.ui.core.mvc" displayBlock="true"
    xmlns:core="sap.ui.core"
    xmlns:l="sap.ui.layout"
    xmlns:u="sap.ui.table"
    xmlns:f="sap.ui.layout.form"
    xmlns="sap.m">
    <Page class="sapUiSizeCompact sapUiContentPadding" showHeader="false">
        <Panel headerText="Validation check using Message Manager" backgroundDesign="Transparent"
            class="sapUiSmallMarginBottom">
            <f:SimpleForm backgroundDesign="Transparent" editable="true"
                layout="ResponsiveGridLayout" labelSpanL="3" labelSpanM="3"
                labelSpanS="12" adjustLabelSpan="true" emptySpanXL="0" emptySpanL="0" emptySpanM="0"
                emptySpanS="0" columnsL="1" columnsM="1"
                singleContainerFullSize="false">

                <f:content>
                    <Label text="First Name" required="true" />
                    <Input type="Text" width="18.5em" maxLength="30"
                        value="{path: 'globalModel>/uiDataInput/firstName', 
                                    type: 'sap.ui.model.type.String', 
                                    constraints: { minLength: 1, maxLength: 30 }}" />

                    <Label text="Last Name" required="true" />
                    <Input type="Text" width="18.5em" maxLength="30"
                        value="{path: 'globalModel>/uiDataInput/lastName', 
                                    type: 'sap.ui.model.type.String', 
                                    constraints: { minLength: 1, maxLength: 30 }}" />
                    </HBox>
                    <Label text="Contact Number" required="true" />
                    <HBox>
                        <HBox width="27em" justifyContent="End">
                            <Input type="Number" width="25em" maxLength="30"
                                value="{path: 'globalModel>/uiDataInput/contactNumber', 
                                        type: 'sap.ui.model.type.String', 
                                        constraints: { minLength: 1, maxLength: 30 }}" />
                        </HBox>
                    </HBox>
                    <Label text="Email Address" />
                    <HBox>
                        <HBox width="27em" justifyContent="End">
                            <Input width="25em" maxLength="241"
                                value="{path: 'globalModel>/uiDataInput/emailID', 
                                        type: 'sap.ui.model.type.String', 
                                        constraints: { minLength: 1, maxLength: 241 }}" />
                        </HBox>
                    </HBox>
                    <Label text="Address" />
                    <TextArea height="7em"
                        value="{globalModel>/uiDataInput/address}"
                        rows="3"
                        width="25em"
                        liveChange="onTextAreaLiveChange"
                    />
                </f:content>
            </f:SimpleForm>
        </Panel>


        <Toolbar>
            <Button text="BACK" visible="false"
                class="sapUiSmallMarginBegin sapUiMediumMarginTopBottom"
                type="Emphasized" press=".navToOverview" />
            <ToolbarSpacer />
            <Button
                icon="sap-icon://alert"
                text="{= ${message>/}.length }"
                visible="{= ${message>/}.length > 0 }"
                type="Emphasized"
                press=".onOpenMessagePopover" />
            <Button text="NEXT"
                class="sapUiTinyMarginEnd sapUiMediumMarginTopBottom"
                type="Emphasized" press="onContinue" />
        </Toolbar>
    </Page>
</mvc:View>

 

MessagePopover.fragment.xml

<core:FragmentDefinition
    xmlns="sap.m"
    xmlns:core="sap.ui.core">
    <MessagePopover
        items="{message>/}"
        initiallyExpanded="true"
        activeTitlePress=".onActiveTitlePressed">
        <MessageItem
            activeTitle="true"
            type="{message>type}"
            title="{message>message}"
            subtitle="{message>additionalText}"
            description="{message>description}"/>
    </MessagePopover>
</core:FragmentDefinition>

 

Real World Scenario

Let’s say a user submits a form without filling all the required fields:

  1. You add error messages to the MessageManager.
  2. The messages automatically link to the empty fields.
  3. When the user clicks Show Messages, the MessagePopover displays all the issues clearly.
  4. After correcting the errors, you can clear all messages and proceed.

Thank you for taking the time to read this blog! 

If you found this helpful, feel free to share your thoughts, feedback or questions in the comments! Let's keep learning and growing together. 

Dear experts, I’m new to blogging, please feel free to correct me if any information is inaccurate.

entry.title: Unlocking End-to-End Change Transparency with DocFlow Reporting by Ovee
entry.content:
Motivation

In today’s complex SAP and hybrid IT landscapes, organizations face increasing pressure to maintain visibility and control over changes, ensure audit readiness, and accelerate delivery. While SAP Solution Manager has long provided powerful tools such as ChaRM (Change Request Management) and ITSM, many customers encountered two persistent challenges:

  • Difficulty accessing specific ticket details hidden in technical tables.
  • Lack of a global overview of change across systems and workflows.

DocFlow Reporting was created to address these gaps — providing extensive visibility, simplified reporting, and automated audit readiness.

How does DocFlow fit into the transition to Cloud ALM?

As customers transition from SAP Solution Manager to SAP Cloud ALM, the challenge is not only to embrace new change management capabilities but also to retain access to historical ChaRM data for audits.

DocFlow Reporting bridges this gap with an archiving solution that secures past ticket information while preparing for the future.

At the same time, we are developing the next generation of DocFlow, designed to integrate seamlessly with Cloud ALM, S/4HANA, and JIRA. This evolution ensures customers benefit from continuity, scalability, and a broader ecosystem reach, taking DocFlow Reporting to the next level in alignment with SAP’s strategic direction.

Process Explanation: Managing Change with SAP ChaRM & Beyond

Every change in an SAP landscape starts as a request, evolves through approval, and is ultimately deployed into production. Along the way, stakeholders need clarity on:

  • Incidents and Requests for Change triggering the change process.
  • Normal, Standard, or Urgent Changes governed by ChaRM.
  • Transport Requests linked to technical deployments and their current position in the landscape.
  • External references such as SAP Notes, SolDoc elements, or tickets from third-party tools.

Traditionally, this information was fragmented across multiple modules. With DocFlow Reporting, users gain a single, consolidated overview of all changes, their dependencies, and their execution status.

Solution & Value Description

DocFlow Reporting delivers value in three main areas:

1. Visibility & Control

  • End-to-end traceability of all change documents and associated transport requests
  • Visualization of each transport position in the system landscape.
  • Dual landscape management with Retrofit transparency and Predict Retrofit analysis.
  • Easy access to Attachments from Change Documents and External Reference

DocFlow allows to have an extensive visibility on all ongoing and past changes accross SAP Solution Landscapes. At a glance, you can review Change Documents and associated Transport Requests including visualization of their position in the Landscape.

 Tracking end-to-end change management process is possible from change initiated in third-party tool up to the deployment in the Production System.

In addition, in case of running a Dual Landscape using Retrofit, transparency on the Retrofit process is given in DocFlow (Retrofit Status) as well as a Predict Retrofit that allows to check Retrofit Categorization for objects before the original Transport Request has been released.

If attachments are available in the Change Document or the related ticket in third party tool, DocFlow makes it easy to review then facilitating the change review.

 2. Audit Readiness

  • Automated extraction for audits, including PDF change records, CSV extracts, linked transport requests with timestamps, and attachments .
  • Easy justification for compliance and IT audit trails.

Collecting Justification for Audit trails has never been easier. With DocFlow it is possible to easily schedule an extraction that can then be downloaded.

Each extraction contains:

  • A pdf file for each Change Document that matches the selection criteria
  • A folder for each Change Document containing the attachments and even external attachments (e.g. coming from JIRA, if any) 
  • A csv file containing the extract of the result screen of the DocFlow
  • A csv containing the list of transport requests (if any) linked to the Change Document that matches the selection criteria along with their export and import timestamp for each system in the landscape

With JIRA integration it can also extract the content of the related JIRA ticket in html format making audit trail even easier.

 3. Flexibility & Extensibility

With DocFlow, you gain the flexibility to focus on the information that really matters and is tailored to your specific needs. It offers:

  • Customizable views: users can select fields and filters that matter most .
  • Variants to save and reuse reporting configurations.
  • Export options to Excel, CSV, and HTML for broader use.
  • Out of the box extensibility to display and filter customer specific fields.

Architecture

The current generation of DocFlow integrates natively with SAP Solution Manager ChaRM & ITSM as well as with third party tools such as JIRA and Service Now.

The next generation, already in development, is designed to:

  • Consume data from multiple sources: SAP Cloud ALM, SAP S/4HANA, JIRA and other third-party systems
  • Provide a reporting layer, ensuring continuity during the transition from SolMan to CALM.
  • Support hybrid scenarios, where historical ChaRM data must remain accessible for audits while new change management processes run in Cloud ALM.

Go-To-Market Plan

  • Today: DocFlow Reporting is fully available for SAP Solution Manager customers. It secures investments in ChaRM & ITSM while simplifying audits and accelerating project delivery.
  • 2025–2026: SAP will deliver extended change management features in Cloud ALM. In parallel, Ovee is building the next-generation DocFlow, designed for multi-source integration (CALM, S/4HANA, JIRA).
  • Future: Customers will benefit from continuity, scalability, and innovation — moving seamlessly from SolMan-based change management to a unified, modern reporting solution aligned with SAP’s strategic direction .

Conclusion

Change transparency is no longer optional — it is a requirement for agility, compliance, and trust. With DocFlow Reporting, organizations gain:

  • Clear, consolidated views across change processes.
  • Faster, simpler audit preparation.
  • A future-proof solution that evolves with SAP Cloud ALM, S/4HANA, and JIRA.

👉Whether you are still running SAP Solution Manager or already transitioning to Cloud ALM, DocFlow ensures your change reporting remains robust, audit-ready, and aligned with tomorrow’s SAP landscape.

entry.title: How to approve/reject tasks directly in SAP Mobile Start app (s/4hana cloud public edition)
entry.content:
Hello,

We have integrated SAP S/4HANA Cloud with SAP Mobile Start through SAP Build Work Zone.
The purchaser and purchasing manager roles have been exposed to BTP and assigned in Build Work Zone.

After completing all notification-related configurations, we are able to receive purchase requisition approval tasks both on the mobile device and on the Build Work Zone home page.

However, to actually approve or reject a task, we still need to navigate to the tenant and process it there.

Is there a way to handle these approval/rejection actions directly from the SAP Mobile Start app without navigating to the tenant?

Thanks in advance for your guidance.

entry.title: Steps to Connect Eclipse ADT with GITHUB
entry.content:
Introduction: By linking Eclipse ADT with GitHub developers can manage source code, collaborate remotely and adopt best practices in enterprise development workflows using Git repositories.

❖ Prerequisites
▪ Eclipse ADT set up in ABAP Perspective.
▪ ABAP Package created (to link with GitHub)
▪ GitHub account and Repository.

❑ Stage 1 - Install abapGit plugin in Eclipse
1. Open Eclipse and select Help → Install New Software.

2. Enter the abapGit URL https://eclipse.abapgit.org/updatesite/
the ‘work with’ section, press enter → select abapGit forABAP
Development Tools (ADT) → click Next.

3. Click Finish.

4. Click Select All → Trust Selected.

5. Click Restart Now.

abapGit plugin is installed now in Eclipse ADT


❑ Stage 2 - Create GitHub Personal Access Token
1. Open GitHub repository you want to link with your
ABAP package → copy the repository URL (you will use
it in the next stage) → go to Settings (click your profile
picture in the top-right corner to access it).

2. In Settings, open Developer settings (bottom of the sidebar) →
expand Personal access tokens → click Tokens (classic).

3. click Generate new token → click Generate new token(classic).

4. Provide a Note (descriptive name) for the token – set an
expiration period – select the required scopes (choose repo to
enable general repository push and pull operations).

5. scroll the page down → click Generate token.

6. PAT successfully generated → copy the token (you’ll use in next
stage).

❑ Stage 3 – Link GitHub Repository with ABAP
Package, Commit Changes, and Push files
1. Open Eclipse → select Window → Show View → Other

2. Search ‘abapgit’ → select abapGit Repositories → click Open

3. Under abapGit Repositories view, click ‘+’ icon (Link New
abapGit Repository).

4. Paste GitHub Repository URL (copied in Stage 2 – Step 1) →
click Next.

5. Add Package Name → click Next → select Folder Logic
(default Full) → click Finish.

6. Click My Repositories → right-click on your package → click
Stage and Push.

7. In the abapGit Staging view → (1) refresh to load the updated
objects → (2) select the object(s) → (3) click ‘+’ icon to Stage
them → (4) enter a Commit Message (optional) → (5) click
Commit and Push.

8. Enter your GitHub account credentials (Username and
Password/Token generated in Stage 2 – Step 6). Tick Store in
Secure Store to save the credentials with your ABAP package
→ click OK → in the Push Started dialog box, click OK again.

Successfully Connected Eclipse ADT with Github

Benefits:-

  • Version Control: Track all changes efficiently, facilitating rollbacks and history audits.
  • Collaboration: Enables multiple SAP developers to work together remotely using branches and pull requests.
  • Code Quality: Supports code reviews and integration with AI tools like Copilot for BAP.
  • Learning and Documentation: Provides a rich environment for reviewing, documenting and explaining code.

Conclusion: By connecting Eclipse ADT with GitHub, SAP ABAP developers again a robust, collaborative environment with modern version control and productivity features. Applying these steps accelerates development, improves code quality and equips teams to meet enterprise standards in ABAP project delivery.

entry.title: Steps for Generating the SAML Assertion to read the data from the Successfactors using IAS
entry.content:
SAP recommends using OAuth 2.0 authentication for API integrations, as HTTP Basic Authentication is deprecated.

In the context of SuccessFactors OData APIs, OAuth 2.0 authentication relies on the SAML 2.0 Bearer Assertion flow. This approach requires an external Identity Provider (IdP), such as SAP Identity Authentication Service (IAS), to generate a signed SAML assertion. That assertion is then exchanged for an OAuth access token, which is used to authenticate API requests to the SAP SuccessFactors system.

Prerequisites

Before implementing the flow, ensure that:

  • SAP SuccessFactors is federated with SAP IAS.

  • A SuccessFactors API user is created, using the same username in both SuccessFactors and IAS.

  • A copy of the SAP IAS signing certificate is available (to be uploaded to SuccessFactors for trust configuration).

Steps :

Please follow the steps below to configure and use it seamlessly . 

Steps for Generating the SAML Assertion to read the data from the Successfactors using IAS for Integration.

  1. Take the SSO certificate from the IAS tenant

Go to Application and resources and choose tenant Settings:

Click on the Single Sign-on Tab and navigate the SAML 2.O Configuration:

Click on the signing Certificates and copy the certificate to register the OAUTH application in Manage OAuth2 Client Applications in Successfactors.

Click on the Binoculars and copy the certificate to use it while registering the Application in Successfactors.

  1. Login to SuccessFactors and go to the Manage OAuth2 Client Applications in Successfactors.

Name

Value

Company

Successfactors instance company id

Application Name

Any Name which is relevant for your integration

Description

Any description

Application URL

Give the application url for which you are going to use this set up.

Bind to users

SFADMIN (or any other API users having admin permissions)

x.509 certificate

IAS tenant setting Signing certificate copy and paste here

API key

It will generate automatically, and we will use it at later point of time so keep it handy

 

  1. Go to IAS and navigate to the application and Resources and choose application.

Create two applications here in IAS system.

  1. OIDC to generate the IAS token having name OIDCTOKEN
  2. SuccessFactors OAuth Integration for generating the token for Successfactors to read the SF data.

 

  1. Go the applications and create and name the applications as OIDCTOKEN.

Application is created as shown below:

Configure the OIDC application to allow password and token exchange: For that you need to click on the OpenID connect configuration.

Keep the grant Types as password and Token exchange (RFC 8693) and save it.

Create secret for the OIDC application and Copy Client ID and Client Secret for later use

Scroll down, copy the client and add the client secret as shown below:

Click on ADD and use the below details to configure and save it.

Client ID and secret will be generated, kindly keep it for later use.

Example of client id and secret!

Client ID: 8b351919-d729-4c6e-ab73-f78d123456

Client Secret: VHJOqEJu4IA2hyA[KzUnm12hr58754

After clicking on OK.

  1. Under Applications & Resources > Applications > Create, create a new application for SF with SAML 2.0 as Protocol Type and the application Name will be SuccessFactors OAuth Integration

Under SAML 2.0 Configuration tab, set the Name field/Entity ID to any you wish and add the SF token endpoint (https:///oauth/token) . In our case the token URL will be https://api2preview.sapsf.eu/oauth/token

NOTE: Do not use existing SF application because special settings are required for OAUTH that is why we are creating a new application here.

Under Subject Name Identifier tab, select Basic Configuration option and set the basic attribute to Login Name:

Under Attributes tab, remove the "user_uuid" attribute and add the "api_key" attribute, setting its Source to Expression and Value to the API key previously copied from Successfactors while configuring Manage Oauth2 application in Successfactors.

Under Provided APIs tab, switch on the "Allow all APIs for principal propagation" option:

Now go back to the OIDCTOKEN applications and add the dependencies as shown below.

Click on ADD and you will be able to add the below values.

Click on Save:

Testing the configuration:

  1.  Triggering API calls to get tokens and data using Postman: The third-party system can use the APIs details and connect to Successfactors using token generation.
  2. The parameters and credentials which needs to be passed to generate the token from IAS. 

 Call IAS endpoint /oauth2/token with target username and password to get access token and ID token for target user. Use Client ID and Secret previously generated in IAS as User and Password for Basic Authentication:

Name

Value

URL for generating the token

https://<IAS tenant ID>.accounts.ondemand.com/oauth2/token in our case. In general, you can take the specific IAS URL for each system.

Header Name: Content-Type

application/x-www-form-urlencoded

Header Name: Authorization

This should be generated as base-64 encoding in the format clientID:Secret on the website https://www.base64encode.org/ The clientID and secret value you should take it from the OIDCTOKEN application step where we have generated the secret and ClientID while configuring in IAS. The value will be Basic <Base64 encoded Value>                        

 

 

  

 

Parameter Name: grant_type

Password (this text password will be used and don’t look for any password)

Parameter Name: username

SFADMIN

Parameter Name: password

The password we need setup for this user SFADMIN in IAS and for the first time you should login to IAS with the new password and it will ask you to reset it. Use the new Password and maintain the same password.

 

Please see the screenshot from Postman.

Parameters:

Headers:

 

  1. Use the access token previously generated in the step 1 (under step 4 postman testing) and call /oauth2/token endpoint to get SAML2-Bearer-Assertion with token exchange

Name

Value

URL for generating the token

https://<tenand-Id>.accounts.ondemand.com/oauth2/token in our case. In general, you can take the specific IAS URL for each system.

Header Name: Content-Type

application/x-www-form-urlencoded

Header Name: Authorization

This should be generated as base-64 encoding in the format clientID:Secret on the website https://www.base64encode.org/ The clientID and secret value you should take it from the OIDCTOKEN application step where we have generated the secret and ClientID while configuring in IAS. This is the same credentials we used above. The value will be Basic <Base64 encoded Value>

 

Parameter: grant_type

urn:ietf:params:oauth:grant-type:token-exchange

Parameter Name: subject_token

access_token value generated in the above steps

 

Parameter Name: subject_token_type

urn:ietf:params:oauth:token-type:access_token

Parameter Name: requested_token_type

urn:ietf:params:oauth:token-type:saml2

Parameter Name: resource

urn:sap:identity:application:provider:name:SFSAML ( This SFSAML is the dependencies name we have kept while configuring the applications:

 

 

 Postman Screenshot:

    Parameters:               

 

Header:

 

 

  1. Call SF token endpoint to get access token:

Name

Value

URL for generating the SF token

https://api2preview.sapsf.eu/oauth/token in our case.

Header Name: Content-Type

application/x-www-form-urlencoded

Parameter Name: company_id

Successfactors Company ID

Parameter Name: client_id

entry.title: Delivery Failed Scenario or Futile Deliveries Scenario with SAP Transportation Management
entry.content:
Delivery Failed Scenario or Futile Deliveries Scenario with SAP Transportation Management

Futile deliveries or deliveries failed scenario is majorly seen with the retail companies where in the B2C scenario with outbound transportation sometimes driver or delivery person could not deliver the goods , due to customer is not available to receive the goods.

If such situation arises there following possible action could be:

  • Inform the same driver or delivery person to redeliver the goods again (keep the shipment until shipment is delivered)
  • Inform the driver or delivery person to return the goods to the source location and plan it again to deliver.

To handle the situation mentioned above SAP Transportation management provides out of the box solution options. These solution options also depend on whether you want to settle the cost of the failed delivery attempt.

Let’s consider we have the below stages in the freight order

and items tab looks like below:

Now for example delivery attempt failed with the customer location “USCU-SCE03”.

To handle delivery failed situation choose the Hierarchy to “Status Management” in the Item tab of the respective freight document.

It provides the below options and shows above in the screen shot:

a) Retry Delivery

Select the package(goods) which was not delivered and choose the option “Retry Delivery” and this will duplicate the original stage. In this case freight unit still belongs to the same freight order the cost of the delivery attempt can be calculated.

In this case since customer “USCU-SCE03” was not available to receive the goods, driver move to next customer location i.e. “USCU-SCE02” and retry to deliver the customer location “USCU-SCE03” again after delivering the customer ““USCU-SCE02”, that is why a new stage has been added to the stages from customer location “USCU-SCE02” to customer location “USCU-SCE03”.

b)Return to Loading Location

Select the package(goods) which was not delivered and choose the option “Return to Loading Location” and system will create additional stage from the last delivery customer location in the original planning i.e. customer location “USCU-SCE02” to loading location as shipping point location “SP_1710.

The item is assigned the cargo receipt status Delivery Failed. Later, a stage is created in a different or new freight document to represent the new delivery attempt.

C) Remove Freight Unit, Keep Items in Freight Document     

When this option is selected then system remove the freight unit from the freight order and this case re attempt delivery cost can not be calculated. Originally there are three freight units are linked to the freight order

After selecting the option” Remove Freight Unit, Keep Items in Freight Document “it decouples the freight unit from the freight order as shown below.
